body_text.text: Alternative splicing is a well characterized mechanism which, coupled with alternative initiation and termination of transcription (1), may expand the transcriptome and proteome complexity in human and other organisms by over one order of magnitude with respect to the number of annotated genes (2,3).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In particular, it is now widely demonstrated that virtually all multi-exon genes may generate multiple transcripts and protein variants (3,4) and that the splicing process is tightly regulated in different physiological conditions, tissues or developmental stages (5).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Furthermore, alterations of the splicing process can be observed in several genetic diseases and in cancer (6)(7)(8)(9)(10).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The authors wish it to be known that in their opinion, the first two authors are the joint First Authors.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: human through the ASPIC algorithm (12-14).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The alternative splicing pattern of human multi-exon genes, determined by ASPIC, has been collected in ASPicDB, a database resource which presents some unique features with respect to other similar databases (15).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The ASPIC algorithm implements an optimization strategy that, performing a multiple alignment of all available transcript data (including full-length cDNA and EST sequences) to the relevant genome sequence, detects the set of introns that minimizes the number of splicing sites.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: It also generates through a directed-acyclic graph combinatorial procedure the minimal set of non-mergeable transcript isoforms compatible with the detected splicing events (14).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The reliability of splicing isoforms detected by ASPIC has been recently established through a comparative assessment (16).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The advent of massive transcriptome sequence data generated by RNA-Seq (17) is steadily increasing the number of validated splicing sites and isoforms in human and other organisms thus suggesting that a fraction of alternative splicing events are the result of background noise in the splicing process (18) which generates non-functional isoforms expressed at low level.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Therefore, extensive research efforts are required to distinguish functional species-specific variants from non-functional ones originated from neutral drift in the splicing process, as well as to asses the biological role of functional isoforms.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The annotation of the protein variants predicted with ASPIC is an essential step for exploring the functional and structural diversity of the proteins originating from the same gene by means of alternative splicing and therefore for unraveling the complex physiological effects of alternative splicing events (19).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Indeed, currently available databases, such as ASD (20), ASAP II (21),ASTALAVISTA (22) and H-DBAS (23), mostly collect information on alternative transcripts at the mRNA level, without considering the effect of alternative splicing on the protein structure and function.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The ProSAS (24) database contains structural information as derived from comparative modeling procedure, but due to the limitations of the modeling techniques, only $15% of the human transcripts are endowed with a reliable protein structure prediction.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: ASPICdb aims at filling the gap of structural and functional annotation of protein splicing variants, by adopting a set of analysis and prediction tools that do not rely only on annotation transfer by sequence similarity.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: It provides a thorough computational annotation of predicted human protein variants including PFAM domains (25), N-terminal signal peptides, GPI-anchor propeptides, transmembrane domains, subcellular localization and other features, also reporting the relevant crosslinks to UniprotKB/Swissprot (26) and PDB databases (27).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: A comprehensive annotation of the domain architecture and other structural features could also be extremely useful to critically assess the reliability of the functional classification provided the GO System (25), which still neglects much of the relevant information for alternative splicing products.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In addition, in consideration of the fragmented nature of the available transcript data, the new version ofASPicDB include the annotation of CAGE tags (28) in order to identify truly transcription initiation sites and discriminate between full-length isoforms using alternative transcription initiations and 5 0 -partial transcripts for which a full-length CDS and the encoded protein cannot be reliably predicted.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The computational pipeline implemented for supplementing the ASPicDB protein sequences with functional and structural annotations is represented in Figure 1 and integrates several state-of-the-art tools for similarity search and for machine-learning based prediction of protein features starting from residue sequence.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: For each one of the 256 939 protein variants coming from 17 191 human genes, a first layer of annotation consists in the retrieval of similar sequences from the two major repositories containing well-characterized proteins, namely:
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: (i) the UniProtKB/SwissProt data base (26) (rel. 2010_07, June 2010), that contains 547 011 protein sequences with curated annotations, including 517 802 principal entries and 29 209 splicing variants (UniProt Consotium, 2010);
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: (ii) the Protein Data Bank (rel. July 2010), that contains resolved three dimensional structures for 50 171 different protein sequences (29).
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Similarity searches were performed with BLAST (30) setting the E-value threshold to 10 À3 .
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: A second layer of annotation is obtained by mapping the structural and functional domains collected in thePFAM-A database (rel. 24.0, October 2009) that contains curated multiple sequence alignments based on hidden Markov models (HMM) for 8691 families, 2985 domains, 162 repeats and 74 motifs (25).
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The PFAM models were mapped on the ASPicDB protein sequences by means of the pfam_scan.pl program (ftp://ftp.sanger.ac.uk/pub/ databases/Pfam/Tools/), based on HMMER 3.0 (31).
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: A second layer of annotation is obtained by mapping the structural and functional domains collected in the Figure 1.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Pipeline for the annotation of alternative transcripts.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: PFAM-A database (rel. 24.0, October 2009) that contains curated multiple sequence alignments based on hidden Markov models (HMM) for 8691 families, 2985 domains, 162 repeats and 74 motifs (25).
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The PFAM models were mapped on the ASPicDB protein sequences by means of the pfam_scan.pl program (ftp://ftp.sanger.ac.uk/pub/ databases/Pfam/Tools/), based on HMMER3.0 (31).
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The third layer of annotation results from the integration of several predictors based on machine learning tools, such as neural networks, hidden Markov models, support vector machines and conditional random fields.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Since most of the methods take advantage of the evolutionary information encoded in sequence profiles, we compiled them starting from the similar sequences retrieved with two PSI-BLAST iterations (setting the E-value threshold to 10 À3 ) from the UniRef90 data set consisting of 6 955 504 sequences (July 2010).
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The first predicted features are the presence of N-terminal signal peptide and of C-terminal GPI-anchor propeptides, with SPEPlip (32) and PredGPI (33), respectively.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Both the methods are among the best available predictors, scoring with accuracy as high as 95% the former and 88% the latter.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: When present, the signal peptide and the propeptide are cleaved from the protein sequence.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The presence of coiled-coil domains is predicted with CCHMM-PROF that is able to locate coiled-coil segments in protein sequences with 80% accuracy (34).
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: a-Helical transmembrane domains are then predicted with ENSEMBLE (35), that discriminates transmembrane from globular proteins with false positive and false negative rates both equal to 3%.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The same tool is adopted for predicting the number and the position of transmembrane segments along the sequence, with an accuracy of 90% on the protein base.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The subcellular localization of globular proteins is predicted with BaCelLo (36), which discriminates four localizations in animals (secretory pathway, cytoplasm, nucleus and mitochondrion) with 74% accuracy.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Table 1 reports some statistics on the data contained in the current version of ASPicDB (version 2.0, August 2010) which refers only to human multi-exon genes annotated in NCBI Entrez Gene (37) with at least one RefSeq transcript (38) and the relevant Unigene cluster (39) collecting all available gene-specific cDNA and EST sequences.
body_text.section: ANNOTATION PIPELINE OF HUMAN PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: In the current version of ASPicDB some more features are available including the annotation of the CAGE tags (28) which define truly transcription initiation sites and a comprehensive protein annotation.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: A total of 12 789 394 CAGE tags have been mapped thus supporting constitutive or alternative transcription start sites.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: To each transcript variant a 'unique identifier' (16) has been associated in order to make possible the unambiguous comparison with alternative transcripts collected in other databases.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: All alternative proteins collected in ASPicDB have been compared with UniprotKB/SwissProt (26) and PDB (29) databases.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The results of similarity searches are reported in Table 2.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Only 17% of the ASPicDB protein sequences are identical to proteins deposited in UniProtKB/ SwissProt database.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: However, 94% of the sequences share significant similarity with proteins annotated in the same database, prompting the possibility of a reliable annotation transfer.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Moreover, 54% of ASPicDB sequences are similar to proteins deposited in the PDB suggesting that their structures can be modeled, at least partially.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: A considerable amount of PFAM models map on theASPicDB sequences (Table 2).
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: On the overall, 71% of sequences match with at least one model.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: This result is in agreement with the reported sequence coverage on the human proteome of the current PFAM release, which is equal to 72.5% (25).
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: It is worth noticing that, although all the models map with an E-value < 10 À5 , only 20% of the matches are complete (that is, involve the whole model).
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: A note of caution is necessary when inferring features from partial matches and the actual extent of the match has to be evaluated for each instance.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Table 3 summarizes the results of the annotation process performed with machine learning based predictors.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Two percent of proteins were not predicted since they are shorter than 50 residues, 16% of proteins are predicted as transmembrane and 82% are predicted as globular.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Among the globular proteins, 12% are predicted as secreted, 35% as cytoplasmic, 27% as globular and 8% as mitochondrial.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Signal peptides and GPI-anchor propeptides are predicted in the 12 and 0.7% of theThe number of splicing sites belonging to the U2 or U12 class and of splicing events is also reported.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: sequences, respectively.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Coiled-coil domains are predicted in 1.3% of the proteins.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: At the gene level, 30 and 92% of genes encode for transmembrane and globular proteins, respectively.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Since the sum exceed 100%, it follows that 22% of the genes encode for both globular and transmembrane variants.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The same consideration holds for the other annotations as reported in Table 4.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The amount of genes predicted to encode for proteins with different subcellular localization achieves 56%.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: This is partially explained by the fact that BaCelLo scores with an accuracy equal to 74%, which is the lowest among the methods included in the pipeline.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Indeed the discrimination between the 'cytoplasmic' and the 'nuclear' classes is still a difficult task for all subcellular localization predictors (40).
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: When the two classes are merged together, the BaCelLo accuracy increases up to 91%, but the rate of genes encoding for proteins with different localizations is still as high as 44%, suggesting that localization diversity is inherent in the ASPicDB protein variants.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: The structure of PFAM annotations is also highly variable: 38% of genes encode for variants matching with different number and/or type of PFAM models.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: Altogether, results listed in Table 4 suggest that alternative transcripts can encode for proteins endowed with different structural and functional features.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: ASPicDB provides a unique resource reporting the annotation of alternative splicing variants at the protein level and an interface enabling the discovery of such differences.
body_text.section: ASPicDB CONTENT AND ANNOTATION OF PROTEIN VARIANTS

body_text.text: ASPicDB can be accessed though simple or advanced query forms.
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: The simple query form allows the user to obtain the splicing pattern of one or more genes selected according to several criteria (e.g. HGNC name, RefSeq or Unigene accession IDs, etc.).
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: The advanced query form allows the user to search for
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: (i) genes,
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: (ii) transcripts;
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: (iii) exons;
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: (iv) splicing sites; and
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: (v) proteins, fulfilling different criteria (e.g. exons in a given length range, etc.).
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: Depending on the choice separate query forms appear.
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: The 'gene', 'transcript' and 'splicing sites' query forms have been described previously (15) whereas the 'exon' and 'protein' query forms are novel features of this version of ASPicDB.
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: The exon query form allows the user to select exons in a given length range, belonging to a specific type (initial, internal or teminal), flanked by specific splicing sites or associated to one or more Affimetrix ExonArray probeset IDs.
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: The 'protein' query form allows the retrieval of transcripts encoding proteins isoforms of a specific class (e.g. globular or transmembrane), subcellular localization (e.g. mitochondrion, nucleus, secretory, cytoplasm) or containing one or more features, including occurrence and number of PFAM or transmembrane domains, GPIanchor propeptides, signal peptides.
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: Finally, it is also possible to retrieve genes encoding for alternative proteins that show differences in the above mentioned features.
body_text.section: ASPicDB RETRIEVAL INTERFACE

body_text.text: After a simple or advanced query has been submitted the output for each selected gene is shown which is organized in eight panels.
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: (1) Gene information reports a summary of the genomic and transcript data used by ASPIC to generate the prediction, downloadable by the user and links to other popular prediction programs such as ASAP2 (21), ASD (20) and ACEVIEW (41) as well as to ASPIC results for orthologous genes in other species.
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: The 'variant type' column lists all the alternative splicing events using a RefSeq mRNA as the reference transcript.
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: The transcript signature is also reported which consists in a unique ID for alternatively spliced variants generated according to (16).
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: (5) Predicted proteins show a graphical representation of the encoded proteins with matching domains (Figure 2).
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: For each mapped domain the sequence  coordinates are reported and different symbols indicate whether the mapping involves the complete domain or only a part of it.
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: (6) Protein table lists the predicted features of the alternative proteins that include:
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: (i) the best hits obtained from the similarity searches against the UniProtKB/ SwissProt and PDB databases, along with the identity value and coverage of the alignment with respect to both the query and the subject sequence lengths;
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: (ii) the features predicted by the pipeline based on machine-learning tools.
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: (7) Predicted splice sites shows the multiple alignment between the genomic sequence and the expressed sequences (i.e. mRNAs and ESTs) near the boundaries (splice sites) of all predicted introns.
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: (8) Intron table lists all predicted introns and their relevant features; All results can be also downloaded by the user in textual format following the 'gene transfer format' (GTF) (see the Gene Information panel).
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: After a query at the gene, transcript, exon, protein or splice site level has been completed, the user can also download specific sets of sequences in FASTA format for further analyses, e.g. genes, transcripts, exons, proteins, 5 0 -UTRs, coding sequences, 3 0 -UTRs, introns as well as sequence regions surrounding splice site boundaries.
body_text.section: ASPicDB OUTPUT

body_text.text: ASPicDB is an ongoing project and we plan to further develop it in the next releases.
body_text.section: FUTURE PERSPECTIVES

body_text.text: In particular we plan to add specific annotations on splicing regulatory elements and their interacting RNA-binding proteins located both in exonic and intronic regions.
body_text.section: FUTURE PERSPECTIVES

body_text.text: We also plan to update alternative splicing prediction by using the huge amount of RNA-Seq data which are now being produced by next generation sequencing, possibly annotating splicing events as constitutive or tissue-specific.
body_text.section: FUTURE PERSPECTIVES

body_text.text: Furthermore, literaturescreened splicing patterns related to diseases will be annotated as they represent potential molecular biomarkers and possible targets for therapy.
body_text.section: FUTURE PERSPECTIVES

body_text.text: Finally, the inclusion in the database of data related to other organisms will certainly favor a better understanding of the alternative splicing process through comparative analyses.
body_text.section: FUTURE PERSPECTIVES

body_text.text: Conflict of interest statement.
body_text.section: Table 4 .

body_text.text: None declared.
body_text.section: Table 4 .
